diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the kidneys, joints, and skin. It can cause inflammation, leading to symptoms like arthropathy, nephritis, and autoimmune hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also have systemic manifestations including anemia and vasculitis, potentially leading indirectly to conditions like synovitis and nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of blood vessels that can lead to damage in various body organs. Depending on the specific type, it can cause symptoms like nephritis, arthropathy, and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily affects the body's moisture-producing glands but can also cause joint pain (arthropathy) and renal involvement (nephritis).

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that has features of several connective tissue diseases like SLE, polymyositis, and systemic sclerosis, leading to a wide range of symptoms including arthritis, myositis, and renal failure.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis and pregnancy-related complications, it can also cause a wide range of other symptoms including hematological (e.g., hemolytic anemia) and renal manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by the triad of hemolytic anemia, acute renal failure (nephritis), and thrombocytopenia. It is usually triggered by infection but can have autoimmune components.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the heart valves which can lead to systemic embolization causing symptoms like renal failure, arthritis, and potential autoimmune hemolytic anemia due to the formation of autoantibodies.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi and transmitted by ticks. When untreated, it can lead to neurological disorders (including delirium), arthritis, and a variety of other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that causes blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to symptoms that may include arthritis, kidney problems, and various systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by acute or chronic inflammation of various tissues of the body, including the joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, heart, and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: A disease that can affect the heart, joints, brain, and skin, which can develop after a strep throat or scarlet fever infection that isn't properly treated.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium, the fluid-filled sac surrounding the heart, often due to infection.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculous Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: A form of pericarditis caused by tuberculosis infection affecting the pericardium leading to the buildup of fluid around the heart.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium, typically caused by coxsackievirus, echovirus, or adenovirus. It's often part of a systemic viral illness.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium that occurs as a result of autoimmune disorders, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own tissues.

diagnoses.name: Uremic Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: A serious complication of chronic kidney failure where waste products accumulate and cause inflammation of the pericardium.

diagnoses.name: Post-MI (Dressler's Syndrome) Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: An immune-mediated pericarditis that occurs weeks to months after a myocardial infarction, as a secondary form of pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune rheumatic disease characterized by the hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can also cause atrophic scarring and involve the heart in the form of pericarditis and other cardiovascular complications.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that displays features commonly seen in lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It can include manifestations like pericarditis and atrophic scarring among its symptoms.

diagnoses: Delirium due to Metabolic or Infectious Causes
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, in the absence of other organic causes)
Hepatitis B or C with renal involvement
Infectious Diseases (e.g., viral, bacterial, fungal infections)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Malabsorption is a hallmark symptom of celiac disease due to damage to the small intestine's lining, impairing nutrient absorption.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This inflammatory bowel disease can lead to malabsorption and may also be associated with skin conditions like folliculitis due to nutrient deficiencies or immune dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.reasoning: Also known as Osler-Weber-Rendu disease, HHT is characterized by arteriovenous malformations. It can lead to various symptoms including malabsorption if AVMs are present in the gastrointestinal tract.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Though not directly causing malabsorption, diabetes mellitus can lead to folliculitis due to immune system impairments. Additionally, diabetes may contribute to difficulty focusing vision.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause hypersomnolence and may contribute to folliculitis through metabolic and immune system effects. Though not directly related to malabsorption, hypothyroidism often presents with a wide range of systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Whipple's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This rare bacterial infection primarily affects the small intestine, leading to malabsorption. It can have systemic effects, though the direct association with the specific symptom combination is less common.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: A systemic disorder that can affect various organs including the skin (folliculitis) and eyes (difficulty focusing vision). It may indirectly lead to malabsorption through granuloma formation in the gastrointestinal system.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease of the central nervous system that might present with difficulty focusing vision due to optic neuritis. It is less directly associated with malabsorption or arteriovenous malformations.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized primarily by hypersomnolence. While not directly associated with malabsorption or arteriovenous malformations, patients may experience a wide range of symptoms reflecting systemic dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.reasoning: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can present with a wide array of symptoms, including skin manifestations like folliculitis. It can also cause renal issues leading to overall systemic symptoms including fatigue.

diagnoses: Chronic Hepatitis C or B infection
Acid Reflux Disease / Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)

diagnoses.name: Loeys-Dietz syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder characterized by vascular anomalies such as aneurysms and arteriovenous malformations, as well as systemic features like skeletal manifestations and skin abnormalities. Decreased immunoglobulins may not be a typical feature, but immune system anomalies have been associated with connective tissue disorders.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. While primarily associated with joint hypermobility, skin elasticity, and tissue fragility, vascular complications like aneurysms can occur, especially in the vascular type.

diagnoses.name: Marfan syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, leading to features like tall stature, long arms, legs, fingers, and toes, and cardiovascular abnormalities such as aortic aneurysms. Gastrointestinal issues like constipation might occur due to connective tissue involvement in the gut.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by decreased levels of immunoglobulins and antibodies, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections. While not typically associated with vascular anomalies or hyperactivity, gastrointestinal issues including constipation can be a feature.

diagnoses.name: Hyper IgM Syndromes
diagnoses.description: Characterized by normal or elevated levels of immunoglobulin M (IgM) and decreased levels of other immunoglobulins, leading to increased susceptibility to infections. This syndrome does not typically present with hyperactivity or vascular anomalies.

diagnoses.name: Selective IgA Deficiency
diagnoses.description: The most common primary immunodeficiency, characterized by an absence or severe reduction of immunoglobulin A (IgA). Patients might experience recurrent infections, and although vascular anomalies and hyperactivity are not common features, associated autoimmune manifestations could potentially overlap with vascular complications.

diagnoses.name: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, X-linked disorder characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), immune deficiency leading to decreased immunoglobulins, and a predisposition to autoimmune disorders and malignancies. Hyperactivity is not a common feature, nor are vascular anomalies or aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: William syndrome
diagnoses.description: A developmental disorder that often features cardiovascular disease, specifically supravalvular aortic stenosis, learning challenges, and a unique personality profile that can include being overly friendly. Connective tissue anomalies can lead to vascular and gastrointestinal issues, but decreased immunoglobulins are not a hallmark of the syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Turner syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by incomplete development at puberty, short stature, and a webbed neck. Cardiovascular anomalies, including aortic aneurysms, are common, but the syndrome does not typically feature decreased immunoglobulins or hyperactivity.

diagnoses.name: Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys, which can lead to various complications, including vascular anomalies like aneurysms. Gastrointestinal symptoms including constipation can occur due to mass effect of enlarged kidneys. Decreased immunoglobulins and hyperactivity are not characteristic features.
Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Cushing's syndrome can manifest a variety of symptoms including muscle pain, easy bruising, and osteoporosis due to the excessive levels of cortisol.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
diagnoses.rationale: CKD can lead to disturbances in mineral and bone metabolism, contributing to osteoporosis and electrolyte imbalances that might exacerbate muscle pain and dyspepsia.

diagnoses.description: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This connective tissue disorder can explain symptoms like easy bruising and joint/muscle pain. However, its direct association with obstructive sleep apnea is less clear but could be related due to potential anatomical anomalies.

diagnoses.description: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: Elevated parathyroid hormone levels can lead to bone density loss (osteoporosis) and might influence muscle pain and dyspepsia through altered calcium metabolism.

diagnoses.description: Polymyalgia Rheumatica
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory disorder commonly causes muscle pain and stiffness. Associated corticosteroid treatment might lead to osteoporosis and easy bruising.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily a lung condition, COPD's systemic effects can exacerbate symptoms like muscle pain and it's associated with sleep disordered breathing, including obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.rationale: Known for causing extensive muscle pain, fibromyalgia can sometimes be accompanied by digestive troubles (like dyspepsia). It doesn't directly cause osteoporosis or easy bruising but can be part of a broader symptomatology.

diagnoses.description: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.rationale: This type of cancer affects plasma cells and can cause bone pain and osteoporosis, among other symptoms. It could potentially lead to easy bruising due to its impact on the bone marrow and blood cell production.

diagnoses.description: Liver Diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Liver dysfunction can lead to a wide range of symptoms, including easy bruising (due to reduced clotting factors), muscle pain, and digestive issues. Liver disease doesn’t directly cause obstructive sleep apnea, but associated conditions could contribute to its manifestation.

diagnoses.description: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: RA is an autoimmune disease that can cause joint pain and damage throughout the body. While RA itself doesn't cause obstructive sleep apnea, systemic symptoms like muscle pain and secondary osteoporosis are common, and inflammation could exacerbate dyspepsia.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's Granulomatosis)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Systemic allergic reactions to food or medications
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.reason: Symptoms including abdominal cramps and sometimes presenting with incontinence due to urgency.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reason: Can cause pruritis due to dry skin or yeast infections, and incontinence due to glucose diuresis.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergies
diagnoses.reason: Can lead to abdominal cramps, rhinorrhea, and in some cases, syncope due to anaphylactic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria
diagnoses.reason: Characterized by pruritis; though the other symptoms are less directly related, systemic reactions can occur.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.reason: Symptoms include abdominal cramps and can lead to incontinence due to malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
diagnoses.reason: Includes incontinence and can induce abdominal cramps; however, the other symptoms are less directly connected.
Can cause incontinence and has been associated with abdominal cramps. It may also lead to systemic symptoms that could explain some of the other issues.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Can cause abdominal cramps, and increased sweating which can sometimes be interpreted as pruritis. Syncope might occur in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Neuroendocrine Tumors
diagnoses.reason: Can present with a variety of symptoms including abdominal cramps and diarrhea, which may lead to incontinence. Can cause flushing and pruritis.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Can manifest physically as abdominal cramps, and sometimes incontinence. Syncope could occur in acute stress reactions.

diagnoses: Toxic Reactions (such as from sea food toxins)
C1 Esterase Inhibitor Deficiency (Hereditary or Acquired)
Irritant or Allergic Contact Dermatitis influencing Larynx

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms but is frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, headache, phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), and sometimes aura.

diagnoses.name: Tension headache
diagnoses.details: A common type of headache characterized by pain that is often described as feeling like a tight band around the head. While it mainly leads to headache, associated symptoms can include mild sensitivity to noise and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Cluster headache
diagnoses.details: A condition that produces severe headaches on one side of the head. It can be accompanied by nausea and sensitivity to light or sound due to the severity of the pain.

diagnoses.name: Viral gastroenteritis
diagnoses.details: Often referred to as stomach flu, this condition can lead to stomach cramps, nausea, vomiting, and headache, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Food poisoning
diagnoses.details: The result of eating contaminated food. Common symptoms can include nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and sometimes headache and fever.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.details: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Its symptoms depend on the tumor's size, location, and rate of growth but often include headaches, nausea, and sometimes sensitivity to noise.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.details: An inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include headache, fever, nausea, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension (high blood pressure)
diagnoses.details: Hypertension can sometimes cause headaches, and in severe cases, nausea. It's more common when high blood pressure is at a critical stage.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.details: Dehydration can lead to a headache and nausea due to the body's lack of fluids. Severe cases may also cause sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Sinusitis
diagnoses.details: Inflammation or swelling of the tissue lining the sinuses that can lead to headaches, facial pain, and sometimes nausea. Phonophobia isn't a common symptom, but severe headaches might cause a dislike of loud noises or music.

diagnoses: Toxic Effects (from substances like alcohol, heavy metals)
Schizophrenia (secondary cause due to systemic illness)
Viral Infection (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
